docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to losing hair, life is, in a way, kinder to men. They have their youth and early adulthood to get used to the idea that they may end up as bald as their Uncle Morty. But for women, hair loss usually comes as a surprise. They may not end up looking like Uncle Morty, but thinning during middle age can be pronounced, permanent and frightening. And dermatologists, whose purview includes hair loss, say it is far more common than women realize.

headline.main: The Secret Loss That Women Try to Keep Under Their Hats

docs.abstract: Estimated 20 million American women are losing hair, according to American Academy of Dermatology; many of these women have inherited genes that, as in men, cause hair loss that can begin when they are in their early 30's; in women, loss is usually more diffuse, but many will have same receding hairline seen in balding men; although genetics is often cause, hair loss can be first indication of several diseases; photo (Special Section: Women's Health) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Gail Heinze delivered identical twin boys in May 1996, at Southampton Hospital on Long Island, she used natural-childbirth techniques without anesthetics. Forty-three hours later, Ms. Heinze, a dental hygienist, and her babies were discharged from the hospital. Her managed-care provider, Group Health Insurance, didn't cover a longer stay. ''I was terribly weak and bleeding profusely,'' Ms. Heinze said. ''I needed more rest. Four or five days in the hospital would have been about right. As it was, it took me a year to recuperate totally.''

headline.main: How Long Should New Mothers Remain in the Hospital?

docs.abstract: Doctors say new Federal legislation requiring health insurers to cover no less than 48-hour hospital stay for new mothers and their infants has had positive impact; but even with the protection of law, new mothers' readiness to go home within a certain time can vary, and managed care companies may not always be open to longer postpartum stays; photo (Special Section: Women's Health) (M)
docs.snippet: WHEN Gail Heinze delivered identical twin boys in May 1996, at Southampton Hospital on Long Island, she used natural-childbirth techniques without anesthetics. Forty-three hours later, Ms. Heinze, a dental hygienist, and her babies were discharged...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: American women are surrendering stature in the work place, much to the benefit of their feet. According to a national telephone survey of 500 women conducted in May by the American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society, a nonprofit organization of orthopedic surgeons that promotes foot and ankle care, 24 percent of working women wear high heels on the job, down from 37 percent in 1990. This downwardly mobile trend pleases Cherise Dyal, an orthopedic surgeon at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx who designed the society's survey. ''We're not high-heel haters,'' Dr. Dyal said. ''We just think they should be like dessert -- a treat you give yourself now and then.''

headline.main: In the Workplace, a Step Toward Sensible Shoes

docs.abstract: Number of women who wear high heels on job is 24 percent, down from 37 percent in 1990; Dr Cherise Dyal, who designed survey for American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society, says walking around all day with feet stuffed into tight, towering pumps can lead to health problems; says it is no surpise that more than 90 percent of all major forefoot problems occur in women (Special Section: Women's Health) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FIVE years ago, a much-wanted pregnancy at age 37 prompted me to seek prenatal testing. I had of course been prepared for the possibility of bad news. But the test results posed a harrowing dilemma unlike anything I had anticipated or been warned to expect. What is more, as a medical writer, I had entered the testing procedure better informed than most expectant parents. Yet I became a prime example of how people can be unwittingly steamrolled by the advancing juggernaut of genetic science.

headline.main: A Little Knowledge, a Lot of Agony

docs.abstract: Kathleen McAuliffe article on uncertainties of prenatal testing; says tests like amniocentesis can detect genetic abnormalities, but they have also become adept at detecting tiny imperfections whose implications vary wildly; says interpreting their meaning is not a precise science; says many couples are forced to make decision on continuing or terminating pregnancy on their own, in the dark; photo (Special Section: Women's Health) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly 1 out of 5 pregnant women in the United States spends at least a week of her pregnancy, and often much longer, confined to bed. Obstetricians frequently prescribe ''bed rest'' to women who are carrying multiple fetuses or who are at high risk for miscarriage, premature delivery or other complications. But being immobilized can have side effects, and a new study questions whether it is even necessary. The study's lead author, Dr. Judith A. Maloni, says that long periods of bed restriction -- from three weeks to seven months -- can lead to cardiovascular weakening, muscle loss, financial hardship and depression. But according to a survey Dr. Maloni conducted, which recently appeared in the Journal of Women's Health, American obstetricians are largely unaware of the side effects. Moreover, Dr. Maloni, an associate professor at the University of Wisconsin School of Nursing, found little evidence that bed rest is beneficial.
docs.abstract: New study by Dr Judith A Maloni, lead author, questions need for long periods of bed rest that is often prescribed for women carrying multiple fetuses or who are at high risk for miscarriage; says long periods of bed restriction can lead to problems such as cardiovascular weakening; study appeared recently in Journal of Women's Health (Special Section: Women's Health) (S)
docs.snippet: Nearly 1 out of 5 pregnant women in the United States spends at least a week of her pregnancy, and often much longer, confined to bed. Obstetricians frequently prescribe ''bed rest'' to women who are carrying multiple fetuses or who are at high risk...

docs.lead_paragraph: IT took Carla and Bruce P. three and a half gut-wrenching years of invasive medical treatments and more than $40,000 of their savings before Carla got pregnant in April. That makes them part of a small but growing population that beat what the New York State Task Force on Life and the Law recognizes as the ''disease'' of infertility. Lucky? Indisputably. First because Carla, a legal assistant, and Bruce, a real-estate broker, succeeded when the biological odds are stacked against a 41-year-old woman conceiving even with high-tech intervention. Second because Carla's new insurance carrier, U.S. Healthcare, paid for the successful round of blood tests, sonograms, laboratory work, egg harvesting, in-vitro fertilization and implanting the resulting embryos. All this was performed by one of New York City's top reproductive medical teams, which was led by Dr. Cecilia Schmidt-Sarosi and her husband, Dr. Peter Sarosi, reproductive endocrinologists.

headline.main: For Infertility Treatments, Now You're Covered, Now You're Not

docs.abstract: Infertility treatment is an expensive proposition, and health coverage tends to be ephemeral, with companies changing policy with lightning speed; new trend in assisted-reproduction is for private infertility centers that operate without the high overhead of a hospital; photo (Special Section: Women's Health) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ABOUT 20 years ago, when I was so young that all my possessions could fit in a Chevy Vega, I was driving to a newspaper job in North Carolina when my alternator went. I had to have my battery recharged at truck stops twice before I finally rolled into town late at night. Shaken, I left my car in the parking lot of a mechanic I'd never met. I don't remember my call home, but I'm sure I made quite a fuss. The next day, unbeknown to me, my father called the mechanic and asked him to take good care of me. Such is the power of dads that the mechanic not only took care of my car but also kept and watered all my house plants until I found an apartment.

headline.main: Once Daddy's Girl, Always Daddy's Girl

docs.abstract: Father's Day column by Debra Galant on lessons learned from her father (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WESTERN thought about sex -- from the story of Eve to Aristotle's belief that girl babies arise from cooler sperm -- has been tainted by the notion that the female is a kind of imperfect or unfinished male. Medical science, however, has gone from treating women as though they were simply smaller men to realizing that sex confers many more differences than those that are related to reproduction. In contrast to the feminist premise that women can do anything men can do, science is demonstrating that women can do some things better, that they have many biological and cognitive advantages over men. Then again, there are some things that women don't do as well.

headline.main: Gender Specifics: Why Women Aren't Men

docs.abstract: Biological and cognitive advantages women have over men discussed in special section Women's Health; science and medicine are finally realizing that differences that exist between sexes necessitate developing distinct therapeutic treatments addressing specifics of our physiology; for example, some doctors are advocating use of sex-specific assessment and treatment of psychiatric disorders, like depression; Dr Susan G Kornstein says that while depressed men seem to respond better to drugs that affect two neurotransmitter systems, women repond better to drugs that affect only serotonin system; says these differences not only underscore need for medicine to go beyond giving women tapered doses of whatever is being prescribed for men, but support idea that men's and women's brains do not function in same way, largely because of hormonal differences (M)
docs.snippet: WESTERN thought about sex -- from the story of Eve to Aristotle's belief that girl babies arise from cooler sperm -- has been tainted by the notion that the female is a kind of imperfect or unfinished male. Medical science, however, has gone from...

docs.lead_paragraph: TEEN-AGE pregnancy is an integral part of the loop of urban poverty: it is caused by, and in turn causes, many of the other problems that prevent young people -- especially young women -- from realizing the full potential of their lives. In an effort to prevent such pregnancies, and knowing the advantage of peers reaching out to peers, the state established the Teen Pregnancy Prevention Program in 1987, now in place in nine cities.
docs.abstract: Article describes goals of Teen Pregnancy Prevention Program, started in 1987 at schools in nine Connecticut cities (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Advice to mothers is as plentiful as air. There are hundreds of books and thousands of old wives' tales. On top of that is the daily unsolicited advice that mothers get from friends, relatives, even strangers on the street. What about advice to fathers? Tucked into books for mothers about what they should expect from their babies and children are usually a few pages telling them what they should expect from fathers (usually very little). There is also a growing shelf of books of advice for fathers: books encouraging them to take a greater part in the children's lives, books ordering them to take back their traditional roles and books jokingly telling them how to handle unpredictably moody wives and children.

headline.main: Father Knows Best, With Help: Kiss the Baby and Wife
